title: Toddler trapped in newborn baby's body - and his organs could soon outgrow him
text:

A 17-month--old toddler suffers from a mysterious genetic condition which means he still looks like a newborn baby.

The parents of Ethan are desperate for help before his organs outgrow his body.

Amanda and Ian Warman, from Slough, Berkshire, welcomed Ethan into the world in May last year.

But ever since then he has been plagued by debilitating health conditions, including growth retardation, abnormally small eyeballs which restrict his sight and an underactive thyroid gland, which genetic doctors believe are all linked to an unknown syndrome.

The fraught couple now face a five year wait to find out what's wrong with Ethan.

(Image: Go Fund Me)

(Image: Facebook)

But there is some hope if they can raise enough money to seek help from specialists in different countries.

Having been born weighing 3.5lbs and 28cm tall, he now weighs just 13lbs and is 71cm tall.

Ian told the the Daily Mail: "Both myself and Amanda have had moments of deep, dark depression, but work together to keep ourselves upbeat so that we can survive."

Amanda, 27, a production operative, met Ian, 32, a recruitment manager, at a work awards gala and a few months after they moved in together, Amanda fell pregnant.

The couple got married in March last year.

(Image: Go Fund Me)

At their 12-week scan, the couple were told there was a possibility Ethan was growing too slowly, but also that it may be nothing to worry about, reports the Daily Mail.

On the 34th week the couple went to Slough for a scan and they called in a doctor to take a look.

At this stage doctors were very concerned as they had seen the placenta had calcification and was stopping food being passed to Ethan.

On May 31 last year, Amanda was booked for an emergency C-section after tests showed Ethan's heart rate was slowing and he still wasn't growing.

Ian said: "Ethan came into the world at 12.04pm and was taken to a small table at the side of the operating room, and they had to bring him to life as he wasn't breathing."

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

Ethan spent time in what Ian called 'the fish tank' in neonatal care and no one could hold him as he was connected to feeding tubes.

And since then Ethan has struggled to grow.

Genetic doctors believe the likely cause is a syndrome, however they are yet to find any issues with his genetic code, and suspect it may be unknown to science.

Doctors are monitoring Ethan's growth and his eating of solid foods and they have insisted Ethan isn't in pain but dad Ian said he 'loves a good cry' and is difficult to soothe.

(Image: Facebook)

The couple struggle for money with caring for Ethan a full-time job - so Ian's boss Agata Palicka set up a GoFundMe page to help raise enough cash for them to seek second and third opinions on Ethan's condition.

Ian said: "We have our first consultation with the consultant pediatrician at Harley Street Pediatric Group next week. This man trained in Boston USA at the children's medical centre and has a large list of medical experience.

"Hopefully he can start the process for a second opinion and get us refereed to doctors that can help our boy in any country."
description: Amanda and Ian Warman, from Slough, Berkshire, welcomed Ethan into the world in May last year but his life has been a fraught one
